reasoning: The critique mostly identifies (real) background assumptions and dependency structure rather than arguing those assumptions are false or unlikely. Those assumptions (e.g., separability of “compute” and “cognitive labor,” and that an SIE meaningfully involves scaling cognitive labor under relatively fixed compute) are moderately central: if they fail, the CES-style bottleneck discussion and some conclusions weaken. But because the critique provides little object-level case against the assumptions, it only weakly refutes the position. Most listed assumptions are plausibly present, and the writeup is reasonably clear, with little outright error. It covers multiple distinct potential weak points rather than a single focused objection.
title: Algorithmic efficiency gains undermine the fixed-input bottleneck assumption
